text: U.S. VP Pence kicks off Japan talks, both sides seek "near term" results U.S. Vice   and his wife Karen arrive at Atsugi naval air base in Ayase By Roberta Rampton and Minami Funakoshi TOKYO (Reuters) - U.S. Vice   on Tuesday kicked off talks with Japan that the White House hopes will open doors for U.S. goods and attract infrastructure investment, putting Tokyo on notice that Washington wants results soon. Pence first joined a working lunch with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe before meeting Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso for economic talks. U.S. President Donald Trump and Abe arranged the talks between their deputies at a Washington summit in February, soon after Trump took office. "When President Trump agreed to this dialogue, he envisioned this as a mechanism for enhancing bilateral commercial relations between the United States and Japan, and achieving results in the near future. And I share that vision and impatience," Pence told Aso at the start of the talks, comments that could be construed as a warning to Tokyo not to use the dialogue to kick touchy topics down the road. Aso in turn said U.S.-Japan trade friction, which soured ties in the 1980s and 1990s, was a thing of the distant past and the allies were now entering an era of cooperation. In a statement after the talks, the two sides said they had agreed the dialogue should produce "concrete results in the near term" adding that they had "discussed specific sectors where improved commercial relations will promote mutual economic benefits and job creation in both countries". Earlier, U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross met Japan's trade minister, Hiroshige Seko. Ross, seen as more hardline on trade, told reporters Washington was eager to increase trade ties with Tokyo through a two-way agreement. Pence landed in Tokyo from South Korea after a trip that included a visit to the heavily fortified border separating the North and South. He described the U.S.-Japan alliance as the "cornerstone" of regional security. Pence's 10-day tour of Asia is aimed at emphasising that U.S. President Donald Trump wants to boost U.S. trade in the region even though Trump has abandoned the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact. Advocates for the TPP, negotiated by former President Barack Obama and supported by Abe, said it would have opened markets for American exports. U.S. business groups supported the deal but U.S. labour unions argued it would hurt American workers. Trump campaigned for office on an "America First" platform, saying he would boost U.S. manufacturing jobs and shrink the country's trade deficit with countries like Japan. Trump also vowed to renegotiate existing regional trade deals to focus on bilateral agreements. Tokyo is wary of a two-way free trade agreement (FTA), fearing it would boost pressure to open up politically sensitive sectors such as agriculture. "It’s a little bit early to say just what forms things will take but we are certainly eager to increase our trade relationships with Japan and to do so in the form of an agreement," Ross said when asked about a possible FTA. TRADE IMBALANCES Japan had a $69 billion trade surplus with the United States last year, the U.S. Treasury Department said, expressing concern over what it called the "persistence" of the imbalance. Japanese officials counter that Tokyo accounts for a much smaller chunk of America's deficit than in the past, while China's imbalance is much bigger. Trump has complained that Japan keeps its currency artificially low, although a Treasury Department report last week did not label Japan a currency manipulator. The issue was not expected to be raised in talks on Tuesday. Pence said in Seoul earlier on Tuesday the Trump administration would review and reform a 5-year-old free trade agreement with South Korea. The Korea Automobile Manufacturers Association expressed concern about any review of the pact, which removed tariffs on auto trade between the two countries. Trump and Abe agreed in February to have Pence and Aso, who is also Japan's finance minister, open an economic dialogue. The two sides were expected to agree on principles and a process for further detailed discussions between ministries. "Obviously, the first high-level talk is not going to have an immediate resolution of anything but I think we have a reasonable path forward," Ross said. Aso told reporters before the talks he would not discuss any bilateral free trade deal with Pence. The White House adviser said Tuesday's talks would not prescribe a free-trade deal but talks might eventually lead to such negotiations. Pence developed ties with Japanese business and political leaders as governor of Indiana, a state that is home to Subaru <7270.T>, Honda <7267.T> and Toyota <7203.T> plants, and about 260 Japanese companies employing about 60,000 residents. "To some extent, we want to do for the United States what we did for Indiana," the White House adviser said. The Trump administration wants to attract more foreign direct investment, hoping to lure some with a $1 trillion plan to rebuild U.S. roads, bridges and other infrastructure. Pence will take that message to upcoming stops this week in Jakarta and Sydney. While no immediate announcements are expected from Tokyo, the White House expects a "handful" of investment announcements while Pence is in Australia at the weekend, the adviser said. He is due to meet corporate leaders at each of his stops. (Additional writing by Linda Sieg; Additional reporting by Kiyoshi Takenaka, Leika Kihara and Tetsushi Kajimoto in TOKYO, Hyunjoo Jin in SEOUL and David Lawder in WASHINGTON; Editing by Paul Tait) First Published: 2017-04-18 03:24:33 Updated 2017-04-18 09:59:30©
title: U.S. VP Pence kicks off Japan talks, both sides seek "near term" results
title_full: U.S. VP Pence kicks off Japan talks, both sides seek "near term" results

author: JRinGeorgia
text:
How much time do you plan to spend in Yosemite Valley ? Since this is your first visit to the park I suggest you be sure your itinerary gives priority to exploring the Valley area itself.
The hiking ideas you laid out represent a very aggressive plan for all but the most trail-hardened, experienced hikers who know they can handle high altitude. You're talking about:
- A Half Dome day of 14 miles and nearly 5,000 ft elevation gain and another 5,000 descent
- A 4-Mile/Panorama day of 13.5 miles and 4,000 ft elevation gain and another 4,000 descent
- A Cloud's Rest day of 14 miles and about 2,500 ft elevation gain and another 2,500 descent (in/out Sunrise)
- What would be considered robust day hikes for many with Yosemite Falls , North Dome and Cathedral.
You're a kid in a candy store, you want EVERYTHING, and that's OK, I think people on this forum can appreciate that. Tell us more about your hiking experience -- your ideas aren't impossible but they would be feasible only for the fittest and most experienced hikers. And have you ever hiked at high altitude?
How many days are you planning for doing all this? Are you expecting to do all of these hikes on consecutive days, or with relaxed days in between?
Do you have the equipment to backpack? If so you would see a lot more and could have a more relaxed pace as well since you won't necessarily be doubling back to civilization every night like with all dayhikes. Your plans have you crossing in and around LYV a few times, with backpacking you could be much more efficient with your mileage, for example hike to LYV and use that as a basecamp to do HD one day, CR another, and then finish by going up the Panorama and down the 4-Mile (or start with the 4-Mile and end with the Mist). Just a thought.
EDIT: was typing my reply when the first reply posted, good advice there too.

author: AussieGirl86
text:
My first thoughts were:
1. Wow, hope he's fit
2. Hope he's got really good knees
3. Hope he's got some time to acclimatise to the elevation
I think Yosemite Falls would we well and truly dry by October, so I'm not sure I'd include that unless you're after the view of Yosemite Valley from above.
Is your Half Dome hike your first day in Yosemite (not including your arrival day)? Will you have a car?
I was going to suggest you consider Cathedral Lakes as a recovery session after Half Dome. However, this would require you to drive from the valley to the high country and back to the Valley. Or you could drive to Glacier Point and hike as much of the Panorama trail as you like and then return to Glacier Point. Then you wouldn't have to worry about returning to your car or repeating The Mist Trail portion that you already covered on your Half Dome hike.
If you have one night in Lee Vining , were you thinking of hiking Clouds Rest before or after that night?
I'm trying to see how you would fit these hikes in:
Day 1: Arrive from FAT (assume in own vehicle)
? what time ? time for a hike ? Glacier Point Sentinel Dome ?
>> overnight in Yosemite Valley
Day 2: Half Dome
>> overnight in Yosemite Valley
Day 3: Drive to the High Country early and complete Clouds Rest or another hike?
Or hike Four Mile-Panorama combo then drive to Lee Vining?
>> overnight in Lee Vining
Day 4: Hike Clouds Rest or hike another (or multiple) shorter High Country hikes
(Cathedral Lakes, Gaylor Lakes, Elizabeth Lake , Lembert Dome and Dog Lake individually or in combination)
Drive to Yosemite Bug
>> overnight at Yosemite Bug
Day 5: (departure) via Mariposa Grove (if open) and drive back to FAT
Hopefully PacificNorthwestFamily will be along soon to give you the benefit of her wisdom on all things Yosemite hiking.

author: Daniel Y
text:
Hi, I will be visiting Yosemite first time this fall and got a permit to hike Half Dome first Monday of Oct. I am also planning to hike the 4 mile-Glacier Point- Panorama- Mist Trail loop as well, though I understand there is overlap b/w this 2 trails (Mist Trail). One other trail I'm interested is Clouds Rest off Tioga Rd. Are these good mix of trails for Yosemite?
I have one more full day, looking for your input:
one more trail in Yosemite Valley such as Upper Yosemite Falls? or in Tioga Road area such as North Dome , Cathedral lakes? Or any other suggestion?
My last day will be a 1/2 day which I am hoping to visit Mariposa Grove if it's open by that time.
Lodging wise, I have 2 nights in the Valley, 1 in Lee Vining (easy access to Tioga?), 1 in Yosemite Bug (to save money), and will be using FAT.
TIA
